journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: The guidance system design of the semi-strapdown homing guided missile

article-meta.aff: 1School of Aerospace Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, People’s Republic of China
2China Aerospace Science and Industry Corp., People’s Republic of China
3Sichuan Jiuzhou Electric Group Corp. Ltd, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Jianmei Song, Key Laboratory of Dynamics and Control of Flight Vehicle, Ministry of Education, School of Aerospace Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, People’s Republic of China. Email: sjm318@bit.edu.cn

abstract.p: The present paper focuses mainly on the semi-strapdown homing guided system design, which includes control system design of the two-degree-of-freedom semi-strapdown homing seeker and estimation of the guidance information. According to Euler dynamics theory and momentum moment theorem, the two-degree-of-freedom nonlinear dynamic model of the semi-strapdown homing seeker is built in common coordinate frames. Then the control-oriented state-space model of the semi-strapdown homing seeker system is proposed innovatively, and a nonlinear controller is designed by integrating the feedback linearization and linear lead controller. Next, the estimation and construction method of the guidance information based on the unscented Kalman filter is presented for the semi-strapdown homing guided missile. Finally, a three-dimensional interception flight simulation is made using the six-degree-of-freedom axial-symmetry nonlinear aerodynamic model of the semi-strapdown homing guided missile. Simulation results show that guidance information of the semi-strapdown homing guided missile can be estimated via the unscented Kalman filter, and can be used in shaping seeker control command. The seeker nonlinear controller based on feedback linearization can improve the disturbance rejection effect of the semi-strapdown homing seeker effectively with good target tracking ability.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The rate gyro set of the semi-strapdown homing seeker (SSHS) is removed from the gimbals and fixed on the missile body, so the SSHS has a relatively simple mechanical structure; it can be made smaller in volume and is lower in cost, which makes the SSHS a fit for many low-cost tactical missiles. The main disadvantage of the SSHS is that there is no special mechanical stabilization platform in the seeker system to isolate the missile body movement, which may make the seeker lose the target with missile body disturbance. Besides, proportional navigation information cannot be directly given by the SSHS. Therefore, the control system design of the seeker optical axis and the estimation of the guidance information are two key technologies of a semi-strapdown homing guided (SSHG) missile.

In recent years, scholars have conducted much research on these two technologies. The dynamic model of a two-degree-of-freedom (2-DOF) SSHS was built and a linear proportional–derivative (PD) controller was utilized in the optical axis stabilization loop, and also the extended Kalman filter (EKF) was used to estimate the gimbal angular rate to construct the guidance information for proportional navigation, by Waldmann.1 Since the dynamic model of the SSHS was seriously nonlinear, the estimation precision of the guidance information based on the EKF was lower, and furthermore the additional actuator dynamics with inertial time-constant T=1 in the guidance loop led to large miss distance when the initial distance between the missile and the target was close. Not considering the seeker dynamics, an optical axis stabilization method was proposed by Zhou et al.,2 the aim of which was to make the pointing of the optical axis fixed when the target was motionless and the missile body was rotated; but the line of sight (LOS) angular rate in the inertial space could not be directly given by this method also. Kennedy and Kennedy3 contrasted the optical axis stabilization scheme of the platform-stabilized seeker with that of the SSHS, and showed their advantages and disadvantages respectively. Those authors studied the influence of LOS disturbances and sensor noises on the seeker optical axis, and analyzed in detail how the disturbances were coupled to the LOS tracking vector. It was emphasized that further research should be made on how to reduce the influence of disturbances, since more error sources and disturbances would appear in the semi-strapdown optical axis stabilization system. This topic is exactly the focus of our research.

The present paper improves the estimation precision of previous work1 by using the unscented Kalman filter (UKF), and presents the optical axis stabilization method via feedback linearization based on the control-oriented dynamic model of the SSHS. The structure of the paper is as follows. First, a 2-DOF mathematical model of the SSHS dynamics in the common coordinate frames is built and the control-oriented model of the SSHS is proposed, then the stabilization and tracking control system of the seeker optical axis is designed by integrating feedback linearization and classical lead controller. Simulations of the 2-DOF seeker control system are made with missile body disturbance and/or target maneuvering, which verify the better performance of the nonlinear controller compared with the linear controller. Then the gimbal angular rates of the SSHS are estimated based on the UKF, and the guidance information is constructed for proportional navigation. Finally, a flight simulation is made based on the six-degree-of-freedom (6-DOF) axial-symmetry nonlinear aerodynamic model of the SSHG missile.

sec.title: Mathematical model of the SSHS dynamics
sec.p: The dynamics model of the outer gimbal of SSHS will be established according to Euler Dynamics Theory and the Momentum Moment Theorem.5
The momentum moment of the outer gimbal is
The momentum moment of the inner gimbal is

where
Integrating the above dynamic equations of the outer and inner gimbal, we can get the mathematical model of the SSHS dynamics as follows

The equations are similar to those elsewhere,1,2 except for the different definitions of coordinates. When the inertial products of the inner gimbal with electro-optical payload and the inertial products of the outer gimbal are approximated to be zero, then the above dynamic equations can be simplified as follows
where

Thus, the mathematic model of the SSHS dynamics is obtained. It can be seen that the mathematic model is nonlinear and the coupling among the pitch gimbal, yaw gimbal, and the missile body is strong. The feedback linearization method is therefore applied in the following design of the seeker control system.

In order to demonstrate the better performance of the nonlinear controller, a linear controller is also designed for the SSHS under the condition that the magnitude of the missile body maneuvering is small enough, then the pitch and yaw controllers can be designed independently. The schematic diagram of the linear control scheme is shown as Figure 3. The linear lead controllers are adopted as well, and the controller parameters are obtained based on the main linear part of the control-oriented mathematical model of the SSHS.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the SSHS linear control system.

sec.p:
In the following analysis, the controllers in Figure 2 are named as nonlinear control and denoted as
G
nl

G

sec.title: Simulation and validation of the seeker stabilization system
sec.p: Simulations are made to verify the effectiveness of the control system based on feedback linearization with missile body disturbance and target maneuvering. In these simulations, a 6-DOF axial-symmetry nonlinear aerodynamic model of the SSHG missile is used with the assumptions that the missile velocity is very small and can be approximated as zero in the missile kinematics; however, when the aerodynamic force coefficients and moment coefficients are calculated, the missile velocity is set as 200 m/s. Then the attitude of the missile varies with time as a rigid body, but its position changes little. The distance between the missile and the target is always 500 m, the longitudinal axis of the missile body points to the LOS initially, and the optical axis coincides with the longitudinal axis of the missile body at the beginning of simulation. The simulation step is assumed as 5 ms.

sec.title: Simulation of the seeker control system with missile body disturbance
sec.p:
It is assumed that the missile position and the target position do not change in the inertial space, and the pitch, yaw, and the roll rudder are

= 5 sin ( 2 π t ) ∘

, respectively.

caption.p: Pitch and yaw control torques with missile body disturbance only: (a) pitch control torques; (b) yaw control torques.

sec.p:
It can be seen from Figures 5(a) and 4(a) that the difference between the pitch control torques with
G
nl
and
G
l
is small, and the difference between the pitch error angles with
G
nl
and
G
l
is also little. This indicates that the nonlinearity and coupling in the pitch dynamics of the SSHS are weaker. The larger difference of the yaw control torques and yaw error angles with
G
nl
and
G
l
indicates the strong nonlinearity in the yaw dynamics of the SSHS. The phenomenon can be explained as follows: as the rotational axis of the yaw gimbal is fixed on the missile body directly, the influence of missile body disturbance on the yaw gimbal is greater than that on the pitch gimbal, which leads to the stronger nonlinearity and coupling in the yaw dynamics of the SSHS.

The disturbance rejection effect (DRE) of the seeker is defined as the ability of the seeker stabilization system to isolate the missile disturbance. The integrated DRE of the 2-DOF SSHS is defined as follows7

The DRE of the 2-DOF SSHS with
G
nl
and
G
l
is shown in Figure 6(a) and (b), respectively. It is obvious from Figure 6 that the DRE with
G
nl
is much smaller than with
G
l
. This means that the seeker nonlinear controller based on feedback linearization can isolate the missile body disturbance excellently.

caption.p:
DRE of the SSHS with missile body disturbance only: (a) DRE with
G
nl
; (b) DRE with
G
l
.DRE: disturbance rejection effect

sec.title: Influence of varying the gimbal inertial moment on the seeker optical axis stabilization
sec.p: The simulation conditions are set the same as those in the previous subsection (“Simulation of the seeker control system with missile body disturbance”).

When the realistic value of the gimbal moment of inertia is 10% larger than its nominal values, the pitch and yaw error angles and the DRE are as shown in Figures 7 and 8. The solid lines represent the error angles with nominal gimbal moment of inertia and the dashed lines the error angles with realistic gimbal moment of inertia. It can be concluded that varying the gimbal moment inertia will make error angles and DRE increase to some degree. However, the DRE is still below 6%. Robust improvement of the seeker control system should be researched further to suppress the large variation of the seeker system parameters.

caption.p: Pitch and yaw error angles with varying gimbal moment of inertia: (a) pitch error angle; (b) yaw error angle.
DRE with varying gimbal moment of inertia.DRE: disturbance rejection effect.

sec.title: Simulation of seeker control system with target maneuvering and missile body disturbance
sec.p: It is also assumed that the missile position does not change in the inertial space; however, its attitudes are varying. The rudder deflections are the same as those in the two previous subsections (“Simulation of the seeker control system with missile body disturbance” and “Influence of varying the gimbal inertial moment on the seeker optical axis stabilization”). The target velocity is set as 20 m/s, its direction is −45° in the pitch plane and 90° in the yaw plane.

The pitch and yaw error angles of the detector are shown in Figure 9, where Figure 9(a) shows the pitch error angles of the seeker control system with
G
nl
and
G

while Figure 9(b) shows the corresponding yaw error angles. The solid lines are the error angles with
G
nl
, the dotted lines are the error angles with
G
l
. The simulation results demonstrate that the error angles with
G
nl
are much smaller than those with
G
l
. This indicates that the nonlinear feedback control law with feedback linearization can make the SSHS optical axis track the target precisely, and simultaneously isolate the missile body disturbance well.Figure 9.

; (b) yaw error angle with
G

.

sec.title: Estimation of the guidance information of the SSHS based on UKF
Construction of the guidance information
sec.p: The LOS angular rate in the inertial coordinate frame is needed for proportional navigation of the missile. However, it cannot be directly given by the SSHS, and should be constructed and estimated by the measuring information of the SSHG system. The construction method is described in the following.

The projection of the rotational angular rate of the missile body relative to the inertial coordinate frame in the inner gimbal coordinate frame is

sec.title: UKF design for estimating the gimbal angular rates
sec.p: The UKF was proposed by Julier et al. in 1995.8 It is a kind of filter method that aims at the nonlinear system directly. The difference from the EKF is that the UKF does not need the linearization of the system models by a Jacobian matrix. This avoids the error produced by the interruption of higher-order terms. Unscented Transformation is introduced into the UKF, so it is free to debug. The resemblance between the UKF and the EKF is that the implementations of the two algorithms all consist of the prediction of the state mean and covariance and the update of the measurement.9
In the present paper, the gimbal angular rates are estimated by the UKF in the following steps.

Step 1. The state and measurement equations of the UKF for estimating gimbal angular rate are established. Define the state variables as
x

=
λ

. Then the state equations and measurement equations of the SSHS are as follows (neglecting the inertial products)

sec.title: Simulation and validation of the SSHG system
sec.p: In order to test the tracking performance of the optical axis stabilization system and the construction accuracy of the guidance information, the simulation is made via MATLAB. In the simulation, a 6-DOF axial-symmetry nonlinear aerodynamic model of the SSHG missile is used. The schematic diagram of the missile guidance and control system is shown in Figure 10, which is the contribution of the present paper.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the SSHG system.SSHS: semi-strapdown homing seeker; UKF: unscented Kalman filter.

sec.p: The model of the measurement errors in simulation is given as follows.11

The measurement expression of the rate gyro is
ω =
ω

ω

.

.

The initial positions of the missile and target in the inertial space are
( 0 , 500 , 0 ) m
and
( 500 , 0 , 0 ) m
, respectively. The target velocity is 20 m/s with direction 0° in the pitch plane and 45° in the yaw plane. The initial angle between the LOS and the longitudinal axis of the missile body is 3° in the yaw direction, the initial roll angle of the missile body is 5°. The delay time of the image processing unit is 10 ms, and the blind distance of the semi-strapdown seeker is 50 m. The guidance information is constructed for proportional navigation. When the distance between the missile and the target is less than 0.5 m, the simulation will stop. The characteristic curves of the system variables are shown in Figures 11–18.

caption.p: LOS angular rate (yaw).LOS: line of sight.
LOS angular rate (pitch).LOS: line of sight.

sec.p:
Figures 11 and 12 are the trajectories of the missile and target in the pitch and yaw plane, respectively, where the solid line represents the missile trajectory and the dashed line represents the target trajectory. Figures 13 and 14 are the curves of gimbal angular rates
λ
y
and
λ
z
, where the solid line represents the real value of the gimbal angular rate and the dashed line represents the gimbal angular rate estimated by the UKF. Figures 15 and 16 are the curves of the LOS angular rates, where the solid line represents the real LOS angular rate and the dashed line represents the constructed LOS angular rate. Figures 17 and 18 are the curves of the two error angles
ε
y
and
ε
z
.

The mean of the miss distances is 0.4071 m and its standard deviation is 0.0392 m after 100 Monte Carlo simulations. Simulation results indicate that the optical axis stabilization system is rational and effective, and the constructed guidance information can make the missile hit the target precisely.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: System design of the SSHG missile is presented in the current paper. The 2-DOF dynamics model of the SSHS is first built, and then transformed innovatively into the control-oriented state-space seeker dynamics model, whose outputs are the inertial pitch and yaw attitude angles of the SSHS optical axis. Then a nonlinear controller for the SSHS control system is designed by integrating the feedback linearization and the linear lead controller. The nonlinear control strategy not only makes the SSHS optical axis track the inertial LOS accurately, but also isolates the missile body disturbances well, and improves the DRE of the SSHS obviously. The nonlinearity and coupling of the seeker dynamics cannot be ignored in the design of the seeker control system when the missile body is maneuvering in pitch, yaw, and roll.

Considering the nonlinearity of the SSHS dynamics and the limitation of the seeker measurement devices, the estimation method of guidance information based on the UKF is proposed for the SSHG system. The estimated information is not only used to form the guidance information for proportional navigation, but also is applied in the nonlinear controller of the SSHS missile. The results of the flight simulation based on a 6-DOF axial-symmetry nonlinear aerodynamic model of the SSHG missile validate the correctness of the SSHS control system, and indicate that the estimation and construction method of guidance information based on the UKF is reasonable and effective.

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
